title.narrative: Provision of holistic humanitarian support to persons with disabilities in Aweil South and Tonj South

description.narrative:
As a result of the conflict in South Sudan, it is estimated that the proportion of persons with disabilities increased substantially, these included congenital or disabilities caused by mines, unexploded ordinance, the effects of war such as poverty, insufficient access to essential services and displacement. IOM and Humanity and Inclusion (HI) surveys (Malakal 2021 , Wau 2019 , Bentiu 2018 ) on disability inclusion and access to humanitarian services in displacement camps shows that people with disabilities face greater challenges to access services, with greater challenges experienced among women and especially children with disabilities (75% perceive having less access to services, food, education that children without disabilities). There remain high levels of stigma and discrimination towards persons with disabilities, neurological and mental health conditions further reinforcing exclusion and vulnerability to protection and mental health risks.
This Protection project aims to improve empowerment and inclusion of persons with disabilities through three complementary components: a total of 15,530 affected people- 5,440 men, 5,860 women, 1,935 boys, 2,295 girls - will be supported, of whom 3,230 are neglected, vulnerable and marginalized persons with disabilities in the priority counties of Aweil South and Tonj South. In addition to focusing on the persons with disabilities, the project also reaches out, through awareness raising activities, to the wider community among whom persons with disabilities reside. Inclusion of the broader community will assist in addressing the attitudinal and environmental barriers which persons with disabilities face in their day to day lives.
